content: Say ‘no’ like you mean it. The most basic way to respond to peer pressure is to just say ‘no.’ Standing up to peer pressure will save you the trouble of getting pressured again in the future because it sends a clear message that you're not interested. Be firm and make eye contact. This shows that you’re not willing to compromise. [1] There are lots of ways to say no. For example, say, “I don’t do that” or, “No thanks, I’ll pass.” You can also say, “I’d rather not, thanks.” Be careful not to get baited into doing something by being called “scared” or “a chicken.” Stay firm in your own decision. Change the subject if you’re uncomfortable responding to questions. Avoiding the question might send the message that you're still interested but don’t want to respond. That may lead to further pressure later on. Changing the subject, however, will at least buy you some time until you feel ready to respond (or not respond at all). Change the subject by saying, "Do you want to watch this movie with me? I've really been wanting to see it, but it's no fun watching it alone." If someone at a party is pressuring you into drinking, try asking "So what do you think of the DJ so far?" Make an excuse to leave. This is a great option if you're feeling shy or intimidated, or if you don't want to come off as being rude. Come up with some sort of an excuse, apologize, and get away as soon as you can. For example: [2] You could say “Oh, I just forgot, I have to study for the math exam," or "Oh my gosh! I just forgot that I have to meet Sue for that group project!" If the person is persistent, text your friend or your parent to call you. When your phone rings, pick it up, talk for a bit, then say you have to leave. Make sure that your excuse is believable. Don't mention that you have to talk to your sister if you don't have a sister. Make your own decisions. Do things that make you happy and make those decisions on your own. While some people might ask you to do something that pushes you outside your comfort zone in a good way, be mindful of any negative consequences that could occur. If you’re about to make a decision, ask yourself, “Is this good for me? Is this adding something positive to my life? Am I certain how I feel about it?" Don’t make decisions based on what other people think is good for you or what they want you to do. Plan a response. Whether you haven’t experienced peer pressure yet or you want to respond better for next time, think of a response you can use if you’re ever asked something you don’t want to do. Having a response ready will mean you won’t feel under pressure if you’re asked and you’ll already know what to say. [3] For example, think about something to say if someone asks you to cheat, lie, steal, or take drugs. You might use a generic, “Naw, no thanks” or have something different for each situation. Don't get sidetracked by talking others out of the idea. Make "I" statements and stay focused on your own position. Avoid places and situations that make you uncomfortable. If you suspect that people are meeting up to drink alcohol or do drugs before an event, tell them that you’ll meet them at the event itself. Avoiding situations that might tempt you can help you avoid peer pressure altogether. [4] If you're still in school, be weary of going to parties without adult supervision or meeting up with people you know do drugs. Trust your instinct. If something feels "off," don't hesitate to make other plans. If you start to feel uncomfortable during a party, don't be afraid to leave. Choose positive friends. When dealing with peer pressure, start by choosing friends who won’t pressure you do things. Your friends should accept you for who you are without wanting to change you. If your friends don’t make bad decisions, you’re less likely to make them, too. [5] Choose friends because you like them, not because they’re ‘cool’ or popular. They should like you for you and care about you. Try meeting people who share common interests with you. For example, if you see someone reading a book that you like, strike up a conversation with them about the book and get to know them. Journal about your feelings. It can be difficult to deal with the feelings that come from peer pressure. You might be good friends with someone, then feel betrayed when they try to pressure you to do something. You might even wonder if the friendship is over or needs to end. Dealing with these emotions can be hard, so use a journal to sort out your feelings and help you cope with the stress. [6] Your journal should be a safe place to write out your thoughts and feelings. Be honest with yourself as you write. You might want to reflect on your journal entries at times to see how you’ve dealt with things in the past and what was helpful before. Choose a different friend group. Think about your good interactions with them versus your bad interactions. If you feel like they pressure you much more than you’d like or they won’t stop, make some new friends. While it’s hard to say goodbye to friends, it might be harder to keep saying "no" to peer pressure and deal with how it makes you feel. You can meet people by volunteering or attending karate, dance, or other classes. If you are still in school, audition for a play, try out for sports team, or join a club. Pick something that your current group of friends isn't involved in. Keep busy with healthy activities. Another way to avoid peer pressure is to spend your time doing activities that you really enjoy. Doing activities can help you meet other people with shared interests and help you spend your time doing what you enjoy. Try different activities until you find one you like. For example, try a sewing or woodworking class, pick up photography, go hiking, or get a bike. See what clubs are available at school, like drama club, math team, and Big Brothers and Big Sisters. You can also join a sport like soccer, track, gymnastics, or volleyball. Use the buddy system. If you have a friend who has similar values, go places together. You can keep each other in check as well as look out for one another. Back each other up and support each other in making good decisions. [7] For example, if your friend is having a hard time saying no, chime in and say, “We’re just leaving now and going to the mall.” Talk to a trusted friend. If you’re struggling with peer pressure, talk to someone you trust. [8] Your friend might have some advice for how they handle peer pressure that you could use. They can also help support you in handling peer pressure in the future. It’s okay to admit you’re struggling, and they will most likely want to help you. For example, try saying, “Ryan wants to cheat off of my homework but I don’t want to cheat. How do you handle these situations?” Tell your parents . Your parents generally want to support you and help you succeed. If you’re struggling with peer pressure, turn to them for help. They might have some ideas for how to handle it. If nothing else, ask them to listen and understand your experience. [9] They can at least give you a hug and tell you that they love you. Though it might be awkward or difficult to talk with them, think how much worse it would be to talk to them about how you followed your friends and got into serious trouble. Attend therapy if you’re struggling and nothing seems to help. You can find a therapist by contacting (or having your parents contact) a local mental health clinic or your insurance provider. You can also get a recommendation from your physician or a friend. A therapist can help you learn to express your feelings better and build your confidence. [10] Therapists are there to listen to you and offer advice. You can say anything you want without fear of judgement. Sometimes, a therapist just isn't a good match. If you don't feel comfortable around them or aren't making progress, don't be afraid to try a new therapist.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure">How to Deal With Peer Pressure</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Klare Heston, LICSW</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Responding_to_Peer_Pressure_in_the_Moment_sub" id="">Responding to Peer Pressure in the Moment</a>

<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw">Klare Heston, LICSW</a>. Klare Heston is a Licensed Independent Clinical Social Worker in Ohio. She received her Master of Social Work from Virginia Commonwealth University in 1983.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">10 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>If you feel pressured by people to do things you're uncomfortable doing, there are lots of ways to respond. Be prepared to deal with peer pressure by having a response ready. Avoid places where people do illegal activities or other things you feel uncomfortable around. Lean on people for support, like your friends, family, or a therapist.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Responding_to_Peer_Pressure_in_the_Moment_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Responding_to_Peer_Pressure_in_the_Moment">Responding to Peer Pressure in the Moment</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_5039f27be3" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5039f27be3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Say ‘no’ like you mean it.</b> The most basic way to respond to peer pressure is to just say ‘no.’ <a href="/Stand-Up-to-Peer-Pressure" title="Stand Up to Peer Pressure">Standing up to peer pressure</a> will save you the trouble of getting pressured again in the future because it sends a clear message that you're not interested. Be firm and make eye contact. This shows that you’re not willing to compromise.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>There are lots of ways to say no. For example, say, “I don’t do that” or, “No thanks, I’ll pass.” You can also say, “I’d rather not, thanks.”</li>
<li>Be careful not to get baited into doing something by being called “scared” or “a chicken.” Stay firm in your own decision.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_fafef064fe" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fafef064fe')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Change the subject if you’re uncomfortable responding to questions.</b> Avoiding the question might send the message that you're still interested but don’t want to respond. That may lead to further pressure later on. Changing the subject, however, will at least buy you some time until you feel ready to respond (or not respond at all).

<ul>
<li>Change the subject by saying, "Do you want to watch this movie with me? I've really been wanting to see it, but it's no fun watching it alone."</li>
<li>If someone at a party is pressuring you into drinking, try asking "So what do you think of the DJ so far?"</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_63a5517214" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_63a5517214')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make an excuse to leave.</b> This is a great option if you're feeling shy or intimidated, or if you don't want to come off as being rude. Come up with some sort of an excuse, apologize, and get away as soon as you can. For example:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You could say “Oh, I just forgot, I have to study for the math exam," or "Oh my gosh! I just forgot that I have to meet Sue for that group project!"</li>
<li>If the person is persistent, text your friend or your parent to call you. When your phone rings, pick it up, talk for a bit, then say you have to leave.</li>
<li>Make sure that your excuse is believable. Don't mention that you have to talk to your sister if you don't have a sister.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Anticipating_Peer_Pressure_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Anticipating_Peer_Pressure">Anticipating Peer Pressure</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_17b664a929" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_17b664a929')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make your own decisions.</b> Do things that make you happy and make those decisions on your own. While some people might ask you to do something that pushes you outside your comfort zone in a good way, be mindful of any negative consequences that could occur.

<ul>
<li>If you’re about to make a decision, ask yourself, “Is this good for me? Is this adding something positive to my life? Am I certain how I feel about it?"</li>
<li>Don’t make decisions based on what other people think is good for you or what they want you to do.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_55711196f1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_55711196f1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Plan a response.</b> Whether you haven’t experienced peer pressure yet or you want to respond better for next time, think of a response you can use if you’re ever asked something you don’t want to do. Having a response ready will mean you won’t feel under pressure if you’re asked and you’ll already know what to say.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, think about something to say if someone asks you to cheat, lie, steal, or take drugs. You might use a generic, “Naw, no thanks” or have something different for each situation.</li>
<li>Don't get sidetracked by talking others out of the idea. Make "I" statements and stay focused on your own position.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_16e9514e2b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_16e9514e2b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid places and situations that make you uncomfortable.</b> If you suspect that people are meeting up to drink alcohol or do drugs before an event, tell them that you’ll meet them at the event itself. Avoiding situations that might tempt you can help you avoid peer pressure altogether.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you're still in school, be weary of going to parties without adult supervision or meeting up with people you know do drugs.</li>
<li>Trust your instinct. If something feels "off," don't hesitate to make other plans. If you start to feel uncomfortable during a party, don't be afraid to leave.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_25a279db2f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_25a279db2f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose positive friends.</b> When dealing with peer pressure, start by choosing friends who won’t pressure you do things. Your friends should accept you for who you are without wanting to change you. If your friends don’t make bad decisions, you’re less likely to make them, too.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Choose friends because you like them, not because they’re ‘cool’ or popular. They should like you for you and care about you.</li>
<li>Try meeting people who share common interests with you. For example, if you see someone reading a book that you like, strike up a conversation with them about the book and get to know them.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Handling_the_Effects_of_Peer_Pressure_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Handling_the_Effects_of_Peer_Pressure">Handling the Effects of Peer Pressure</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-8-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-8-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_d34c6ebd91" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d34c6ebd91')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Journal about your feelings.</b> It can be difficult to deal with the feelings that come from peer pressure. You might be good friends with someone, then feel betrayed when they try to pressure you to do something. You might even wonder if the friendship is over or needs to end. Dealing with these emotions can be hard, so use a <a href="/Write-a-Journal-Entry" title="Write a Journal Entry">journal</a> to sort out your feelings and help you cope with the stress.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Your journal should be a safe place to write out your thoughts and feelings. Be honest with yourself as you write.</li>
<li>You might want to reflect on your journal entries at times to see how you’ve dealt with things in the past and what was helpful before.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f540963274" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f540963274')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose a different friend group.</b> Think about your good interactions with them versus your bad interactions. If you feel like they pressure you much more than you’d like or they won’t stop, make some new friends. While it’s hard to say goodbye to friends, it might be harder to keep saying "no" to peer pressure and deal with how it makes you feel.

<ul>
<li>You can meet people by <a href="/Volunteer" title="Volunteer">volunteering</a> or attending karate, dance, or other classes.</li>
<li>If you are still in school, audition for a play, try out for sports team, or join a club. Pick something that your current group of friends isn't involved in.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_3b01440c14" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3b01440c14')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Keep busy with healthy activities.</b> Another way to avoid peer pressure is to spend your time doing activities that you really enjoy. Doing activities can help you meet other people with shared interests and help you spend your time doing what you enjoy.

<ul>
<li>Try different activities until you find one you like. For example, try a sewing or woodworking class, pick up photography, go hiking, or get a bike.</li>
<li>See what clubs are available at school, like drama club, math team, and Big Brothers and Big Sisters. You can also join a sport like soccer, track, gymnastics, or volleyball.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Getting_Support_from_Others_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Getting_Support_from_Others">Getting Support from Others</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9a80499d03" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9a80499d03')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use the buddy system.</b> If you have a friend who has similar values, go places together. You can keep each other in check as well as look out for one another. Back each other up and support each other in making good decisions.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, if your friend is having a hard time saying no, chime in and say, “We’re just leaving now and going to the mall.”</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-12-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-12-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_b06a733fef" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b06a733fef')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Talk to a trusted friend.</b> If you’re struggling with peer pressure, talk to someone you trust.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Your friend might have some advice for how they handle peer pressure that you could use. They can also help support you in handling peer pressure in the future. It’s okay to admit you’re struggling, and they will most likely want to help you.

<ul>
<li>For example, try saying, “Ryan wants to cheat off of my homework but I don’t want to cheat. How do you handle these situations?”</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-13-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-13-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a9b5d34fb3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a9b5d34fb3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Talk-to-Parents-So-They%27ll-Understand" title="Talk to Parents So They'll Understand">Tell your parents</a>.</b> Your parents generally want to support you and help you succeed. If you’re struggling with peer pressure, turn to them for help. They might have some ideas for how to handle it. If nothing else, ask them to listen and understand your experience.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>They can at least give you a hug and tell you that they love you.</li>
<li>Though it might be awkward or difficult to talk with them, think how much worse it would be to talk to them about how you followed your friends and got into serious trouble.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-14-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=528247" href="#/Image:Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-14-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-14-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_2e011bca1f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2e011bca1f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Deal With Peer Pressure Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid528247-v4-728px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-14-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Attend therapy if you’re struggling and nothing seems to help.</b> You can find a therapist by contacting (or having your parents contact) a local mental health clinic or your insurance provider. You can also get a recommendation from your physician or a friend.

<ul>
<li>A therapist can help you learn to express your feelings better and build your confidence.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Therapists are there to listen to you and offer advice. You can say anything you want without fear of judgement.</li>
<li>Sometimes, a therapist just isn't a good match. If you don't feel comfortable around them or aren't making progress, don't be afraid to try a new therapist.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<span>Responding to Peer Pressure in the Moment</span></a></div>

<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky" data-aid="528247" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question"></a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="507277" data-caid="508150" data-cqid="507294" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="4240473" data-verifier_id="23578" data-votes_down="5" data-votes_up="8">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What is an example of peer pressure?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3a/Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg/-crop-200-200-200px-Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" target="_blank">Klare Heston, LICSW</a><br/>
	Clinical Social Worker
</div>
Klare Heston is a Licensed Independent Clinical Social Worker in Ohio. She received her Master of Social Work from Virginia Commonwealth University in 1983.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3a/Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg/-crop-200-200-200px-Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" target="_blank">Klare Heston, LICSW</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Clinical Social Worker</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">For example, when your friends want to drink at a party where the parents clearly stated there is to be no alcohol, but others say something like, "Hey, everyone will having something--you can't party without at least some beer." You might feel conflicted because you want to fit in, but also want to comply with the parents' request.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>5</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>8</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="507275" data-caid="508148" data-cqid="507292" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="4240473" data-verifier_id="23578" data-votes_down="6" data-votes_up="6">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How can you resist peer pressure?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3a/Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg/-crop-200-200-200px-Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" target="_blank">Klare Heston, LICSW</a><br/>
	Clinical Social Worker
</div>
Klare Heston is a Licensed Independent Clinical Social Worker in Ohio. She received her Master of Social Work from Virginia Commonwealth University in 1983.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3a/Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg/-crop-200-200-200px-Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" target="_blank">Klare Heston, LICSW</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Clinical Social Worker</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You can resist peer pressure by thinking things through for yourself, and figuring where you stand on the risks of the situation.  Is the trouble you might get into as a result of the behavior of the group worth maybe being called a name or getting some pressure from your friends?  You could make a quick pro and con list, then make a decision based on that.  You can also try being part of more than one group to dilute the impact of peer pressure.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>6</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>6</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="507276" data-caid="508149" data-cqid="507293" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="4240473" data-verifier_id="23578" data-votes_down="11" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What are the main causes of peer pressure?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3a/Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg/-crop-200-200-200px-Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" target="_blank">Klare Heston, LICSW</a><br/>
	Clinical Social Worker
</div>
Klare Heston is a Licensed Independent Clinical Social Worker in Ohio. She received her Master of Social Work from Virginia Commonwealth University in 1983.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3a/Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg/-crop-200-200-200px-Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" target="_blank">Klare Heston, LICSW</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Clinical Social Worker</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Peer pressure results from wanting to be liked and accepted by your friends.  You don't want to stand out or be different.  You just to blend in with those you really like, and don't want to question their behavior.  You just want to "be like everyone else."  Friendships are very important, and you don't want to be excluded from the group.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>11</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>5</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="507278" data-caid="508151" data-cqid="507295" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="4240473" data-verifier_id="23578" data-votes_down="7" data-votes_up="1">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is peer pressure a good thing?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3a/Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg/-crop-200-200-200px-Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" target="_blank">Klare Heston, LICSW</a><br/>
	Clinical Social Worker
</div>
Klare Heston is a Licensed Independent Clinical Social Worker in Ohio. She received her Master of Social Work from Virginia Commonwealth University in 1983.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3a/Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg/-crop-200-200-200px-Klare_Hestonv3.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=klareheston%2Clicsw#klareheston%2Clicsw" target="_blank">Klare Heston, LICSW</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Clinical Social Worker</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Peer pressure can be both a positive and a negative thing depending on the topic involved.  Lots of times you can do the right thing because you don't want to go against the crowd or the rules or the expectations. It can also be negative when you don't think something through for yourself, and just blindly go along. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To deal with peer pressure, make eye contact and say "no" firmly to show that you're not willing to compromise. You can also change the subject or make an excuse to leave if you feel uncomfortable. Try to avoid going places where it's likely you'll be pressured into something you don't want to do, and consider finding a new group of friends if the pressure continues. Remember that it's totally okay to say "no" if you don't want to do something, and confide in a friend, parent, or counselor if you're struggling to deal with the situation. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For more tips on finding a support system, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

}</script><script type="application/ld+json">{
    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Deal With Peer Pressure",
    "name": "Deal With Peer Pressure",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure"
    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/51\/Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\/aid528247-v4-1200px-Deal-With-Peer-Pressure-Step-14-Version-2.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",
        "bestRating": 100,
        "ratingCount": 82,
        "ratingValue": 85
    },
    "datePublished": "2009-01-12",
    "dateModified": "2019-03-29",
    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Klare Heston, LICSW"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Responding to Peer Pressure in the Moment",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Say \u2018no\u2019 like you mean it. The most basic way to respond to peer pressure is to just say \u2018no.\u2019 Standing up to peer pressure will save you the trouble of getting pressured again in the future because it sends a clear message that you're not interested. Be firm and make eye contact. This shows that you\u2019re not willing to compromise.[1]\nThere are lots of ways to say no. For example, say, \u201cI don\u2019t do that\u201d or, \u201cNo thanks, I\u2019ll pass.\u201d You can also say, \u201cI\u2019d rather not, thanks.\u201d\nBe careful not to get baited into doing something by being called \u201cscared\u201d or \u201ca chicken.\u201d Stay firm in your own decision."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Change the subject if you\u2019re uncomfortable responding to questions. Avoiding the question might send the message that you're still interested but don\u2019t want to respond. That may lead to further pressure later on. Changing the subject, however, will at least buy you some time until you feel ready to respond (or not respond at all).\n\nChange the subject by saying, \"Do you want to watch this movie with me? I've really been wanting to see it, but it's no fun watching it alone.\"\nIf someone at a party is pressuring you into drinking, try asking \"So what do you think of the DJ so far?\""
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Make an excuse to leave. This is a great option if you're feeling shy or intimidated, or if you don't want to come off as being rude. Come up with some sort of an excuse, apologize, and get away as soon as you can. For example:[2]\nYou could say \u201cOh, I just forgot, I have to study for the math exam,\" or \"Oh my gosh! I just forgot that I have to meet Sue for that group project!\"\nIf the person is persistent, text your friend or your parent to call you. When your phone rings, pick it up, talk for a bit, then say you have to leave.\nMake sure that your excuse is believable. Don't mention that you have to talk to your sister if you don't have a sister."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Anticipating Peer Pressure",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Make your own decisions. Do things that make you happy and make those decisions on your own. While some people might ask you to do something that pushes you outside your comfort zone in a good way, be mindful of any negative consequences that could occur.\n\nIf you\u2019re about to make a decision, ask yourself, \u201cIs this good for me? Is this adding something positive to my life? Am I certain how I feel about it?\"\nDon\u2019t make decisions based on what other people think is good for you or what they want you to do."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Plan a response. Whether you haven\u2019t experienced peer pressure yet or you want to respond better for next time, think of a response you can use if you\u2019re ever asked something you don\u2019t want to do. Having a response ready will mean you won\u2019t feel under pressure if you\u2019re asked and you\u2019ll already know what to say.[3]\nFor example, think about something to say if someone asks you to cheat, lie, steal, or take drugs. You might use a generic, \u201cNaw, no thanks\u201d or have something different for each situation.\nDon't get sidetracked by talking others out of the idea. Make \"I\" statements and stay focused on your own position."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid places and situations that make you uncomfortable. If you suspect that people are meeting up to drink alcohol or do drugs before an event, tell them that you\u2019ll meet them at the event itself. Avoiding situations that might tempt you can help you avoid peer pressure altogether.[4]\nIf you're still in school, be weary of going to parties without adult supervision or meeting up with people you know do drugs.\nTrust your instinct. If something feels \"off,\" don't hesitate to make other plans. If you start to feel uncomfortable during a party, don't be afraid to leave."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose positive friends. When dealing with peer pressure, start by choosing friends who won\u2019t pressure you do things. Your friends should accept you for who you are without wanting to change you. If your friends don\u2019t make bad decisions, you\u2019re less likely to make them, too.[5]\nChoose friends because you like them, not because they\u2019re \u2018cool\u2019 or popular. They should like you for you and care about you.\nTry meeting people who share common interests with you. For example, if you see someone reading a book that you like, strike up a conversation with them about the book and get to know them."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Handling the Effects of Peer Pressure",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Journal about your feelings. It can be difficult to deal with the feelings that come from peer pressure. You might be good friends with someone, then feel betrayed when they try to pressure you to do something. You might even wonder if the friendship is over or needs to end. Dealing with these emotions can be hard, so use a journal to sort out your feelings and help you cope with the stress.[6]\nYour journal should be a safe place to write out your thoughts and feelings. Be honest with yourself as you write.\nYou might want to reflect on your journal entries at times to see how you\u2019ve dealt with things in the past and what was helpful before."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose a different friend group. Think about your good interactions with them versus your bad interactions. If you feel like they pressure you much more than you\u2019d like or they won\u2019t stop, make some new friends. While it\u2019s hard to say goodbye to friends, it might be harder to keep saying \"no\" to peer pressure and deal with how it makes you feel.\n\nYou can meet people by volunteering or attending karate, dance, or other classes.\nIf you are still in school, audition for a play, try out for sports team, or join a club. Pick something that your current group of friends isn't involved in."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Keep busy with healthy activities. Another way to avoid peer pressure is to spend your time doing activities that you really enjoy. Doing activities can help you meet other people with shared interests and help you spend your time doing what you enjoy.\n\nTry different activities until you find one you like. For example, try a sewing or woodworking class, pick up photography, go hiking, or get a bike.\nSee what clubs are available at school, like drama club, math team, and Big Brothers and Big Sisters. You can also join a sport like soccer, track, gymnastics, or volleyball."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Getting Support from Others",
            "position": 4,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use the buddy system. If you have a friend who has similar values, go places together. You can keep each other in check as well as look out for one another. Back each other up and support each other in making good decisions.[7]\nFor example, if your friend is having a hard time saying no, chime in and say, \u201cWe\u2019re just leaving now and going to the mall.\u201d"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Talk to a trusted friend. If you\u2019re struggling with peer pressure, talk to someone you trust.[8] Your friend might have some advice for how they handle peer pressure that you could use. They can also help support you in handling peer pressure in the future. It\u2019s okay to admit you\u2019re struggling, and they will most likely want to help you.\n\nFor example, try saying, \u201cRyan wants to cheat off of my homework but I don\u2019t want to cheat. How do you handle these situations?\u201d"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Tell your parents. Your parents generally want to support you and help you succeed. If you\u2019re struggling with peer pressure, turn to them for help. They might have some ideas for how to handle it. title: How to Deal With Peer Pressure
content_html:
Say ‘no’ like you mean it. The most basic way to respond to peer pressure is to just say ‘no.’ Standing up to peer pressure will save you the trouble of getting pressured again in the future because it sends a clear message that you're not interested. Be firm and make eye contact. This shows that you’re not willing to compromise.[1]
  • There are lots of ways to say no. For example, say, “I don’t do that” or, “No thanks, I’ll pass.” You can also say, “I’d rather not, thanks.”
  • Be careful not to get baited into doing something by being called “scared” or “a chicken.” Stay firm in your own decision.
Change the subject if you’re uncomfortable responding to questions. Avoiding the question might send the message that you're still interested but don’t want to respond. That may lead to further pressure later on. Changing the subject, however, will at least buy you some time until you feel ready to respond (or not respond at all).
  • Change the subject by saying, "Do you want to watch this movie with me? I've really been wanting to see it, but it's no fun watching it alone."
  • If someone at a party is pressuring you into drinking, try asking "So what do you think of the DJ so far?"
Make an excuse to leave. This is a great option if you're feeling shy or intimidated, or if you don't want to come off as being rude. Come up with some sort of an excuse, apologize, and get away as soon as you can. For example:[2]
  • You could say “Oh, I just forgot, I have to study for the math exam," or "Oh my gosh! I just forgot that I have to meet Sue for that group project!"
  • If the person is persistent, text your friend or your parent to call you. When your phone rings, pick it up, talk for a bit, then say you have to leave.
  • Make sure that your excuse is believable. Don't mention that you have to talk to your sister if you don't have a sister.
Make your own decisions. Do things that make you happy and make those decisions on your own. While some people might ask you to do something that pushes you outside your comfort zone in a good way, be mindful of any negative consequences that could occur.
  • If you’re about to make a decision, ask yourself, “Is this good for me? Is this adding something positive to my life? Am I certain how I feel about it?"
  • Don’t make decisions based on what other people think is good for you or what they want you to do.
Plan a response. Whether you haven’t experienced peer pressure yet or you want to respond better for next time, think of a response you can use if you’re ever asked something you don’t want to do. Having a response ready will mean you won’t feel under pressure if you’re asked and you’ll already know what to say.[3]
  • For example, think about something to say if someone asks you to cheat, lie, steal, or take drugs. You might use a generic, “Naw, no thanks” or have something different for each situation.
  • Don't get sidetracked by talking others out of the idea. Make "I" statements and stay focused on your own position.
Avoid places and situations that make you uncomfortable. If you suspect that people are meeting up to drink alcohol or do drugs before an event, tell them that you’ll meet them at the event itself. Avoiding situations that might tempt you can help you avoid peer pressure altogether.[4]
  • If you're still in school, be weary of going to parties without adult supervision or meeting up with people you know do drugs.
  • Trust your instinct. If something feels "off," don't hesitate to make other plans. If you start to feel uncomfortable during a party, don't be afraid to leave.
Choose positive friends. When dealing with peer pressure, start by choosing friends who won’t pressure you do things. Your friends should accept you for who you are without wanting to change you. If your friends don’t make bad decisions, you’re less likely to make them, too.[5]
  • Choose friends because you like them, not because they’re ‘cool’ or popular. They should like you for you and care about you.
  • Try meeting people who share common interests with you. For example, if you see someone reading a book that you like, strike up a conversation with them about the book and get to know them.
Journal about your feelings. It can be difficult to deal with the feelings that come from peer pressure. You might be good friends with someone, then feel betrayed when they try to pressure you to do something. You might even wonder if the friendship is over or needs to end. Dealing with these emotions can be hard, so use a journal to sort out your feelings and help you cope with the stress.[6]
  • Your journal should be a safe place to write out your thoughts and feelings. Be honest with yourself as you write.
  • You might want to reflect on your journal entries at times to see how you’ve dealt with things in the past and what was helpful before.
Choose a different friend group. Think about your good interactions with them versus your bad interactions. If you feel like they pressure you much more than you’d like or they won’t stop, make some new friends. While it’s hard to say goodbye to friends, it might be harder to keep saying "no" to peer pressure and deal with how it makes you feel.
  • You can meet people by volunteering or attending karate, dance, or other classes.
  • If you are still in school, audition for a play, try out for sports team, or join a club. Pick something that your current group of friends isn't involved in.
Keep busy with healthy activities. Another way to avoid peer pressure is to spend your time doing activities that you really enjoy. Doing activities can help you meet other people with shared interests and help you spend your time doing what you enjoy.
  • Try different activities until you find one you like. For example, try a sewing or woodworking class, pick up photography, go hiking, or get a bike.
  • See what clubs are available at school, like drama club, math team, and Big Brothers and Big Sisters. You can also join a sport like soccer, track, gymnastics, or volleyball.
Use the buddy system. If you have a friend who has similar values, go places together. You can keep each other in check as well as look out for one another. Back each other up and support each other in making good decisions.[7]
  • For example, if your friend is having a hard time saying no, chime in and say, “We’re just leaving now and going to the mall.”
Talk to a trusted friend. If you’re struggling with peer pressure, talk to someone you trust.[8] Your friend might have some advice for how they handle peer pressure that you could use. They can also help support you in handling peer pressure in the future. It’s okay to admit you’re struggling, and they will most likely want to help you.
  • For example, try saying, “Ryan wants to cheat off of my homework but I don’t want to cheat. How do you handle these situations?”
Tell your parents. Your parents generally want to support you and help you succeed. If you’re struggling with peer pressure, turn to them for help. They might have some ideas for how to handle it. If nothing else, ask them to listen and understand your experience.[9]
  • They can at least give you a hug and tell you that they love you.
  • Though it might be awkward or difficult to talk with them, think how much worse it would be to talk to them about how you followed your friends and got into serious trouble.
Attend therapy if you’re struggling and nothing seems to help. You can find a therapist by contacting (or having your parents contact) a local mental health clinic or your insurance provider. You can also get a recommendation from your physician or a friend.
  • A therapist can help you learn to express your feelings better and build your confidence.[10]
  • Therapists are there to listen to you and offer advice. You can say anything you want without fear of judgement.
  • Sometimes, a therapist just isn't a good match. If you don't feel comfortable around them or aren't making progress, don't be afraid to try a new therapist.
